lg.l: Which that this troubly world hath ay on honde,
That othir thyng than fruyt of bittirnesse
Ne yildith naght, as I can undirstonde,
At Chestres In, right faste by the Stronde,
As I lay in my bed upon a nyght,
Thoght me byrefte of sleep the force and might.
And many a day and nyght that wikkid hyne
Hadde beforn vexed my poore goost
So grevously that of angwissh and pyne
No rycher man was nowhere in no coost.
This dar I seyn, may no wight make his boost
That he with thoght was bet than I aqweynted,
For to the deeth he wel ny hath me feynted.
Bysyly in my mynde I gan revolve
The welthe unseur of every creature,

spanGrp.span: Specific place (Chester Inn) and time creates narrative context of entering dream.
Recollection of past duration starts to merge past and present times, acting as a descriptive tool of thought processes.
Remembers Richard II’s fall, setting political time of narrative.
To emphasise transitory nature of secular fortune
Authenticating strategy of narrative voice
Links back to opening of narrative, bringing reader into presence of the narrative moment that is a recollection
Narrator’s inability to sleep, due to dream setting
of the temporal hoursSpeech on opposites, as narrator wants solitude not joy, analogy to discordant relationship between night and day
Narrative return to L 78, the moment after the abstract duration of the night
Focus on precision here, sets narrative context of physical activity to begin after torturous night.
Old man generalising about young, inexperienced and seldom wise state to waking Hoccleve-narrator.
Hoccleve-narrator tells Old Man there is no point in wasting time until evening talking, as in too much pain.
Old Man instructs Hoccleve-narrator to do as told and not be ruled by negative attributes of youth, and then will be cured.
Old Man cites the authority of the Bible when advocating counsel.
Solomon’s advice in form of warning of brevity of life, about the impending end of one’s time.
How the thought of death torments people in various ways. Duration and continuance conveyed here, with no satisfaction.
The Old Man suffers and endures.
Old Man indicates to Hoccleve-narrator that this is the propitious moment to expel such thoughts.
This moment brings the closure of the narrative episode of burning of the Lollard of John Badby (which helps date the poem), which enables the commentary on the event to begin.
Old Man reckons he has made good sense, and lists positives of the mind in old age (in lines 402-5), emphasising that the negatives are only in relation to the physical body.
